newsitem.title: COLOMBIA: Twin blast injures five in northeast Colombia.
newsitem.headline: Twin blast injures five in northeast Colombia.

text.p: Two bombs exploded in northeast Colombia early on Wednesday, injuring five people, in the latest dynamite attacks by leftist guerrillas, police said.
The blasts in downtown Bucaramanga, Santander province, came on the same day that President Ernesto Samper and National Police chief Gen. Rosso Jose Serrano were scheduled to visit the city.
"Terrorism has arrived in our city. This marks the escalation of a wave of bombings in the east of the country," said city mayor Carlos Ibanez.
A police spokesman said two men were captured shortly after the explosions, which damaged the premises of a cattle ranchers' association and the chamber of commerce.
He said the National Liberation Army (ELN), Colombia's second largest rebel group set up by radical Roman Catholic priests in the mid-1960s, was thought to be behind the attacks.
The attacks came 24 hours after two car bombs exploded in Cucuta, in neighbouring Norte de Santander province, in which an 18-month-old girl died.
